{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3342057,"name":"Amit sucher","username":"AmitSucher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/amitsucher/{size}/257401_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-24T21:41:42.141Z","cooked":"

Second year in a row that our robot does not work because of some products like encoders / motors (and also wiring issues)

This year, we improved a ton mechanically, and everything went well, yet many of our matches we lost just because our robot stopped working, encoders on the swerve… vortex on the swerve breaking multiple times and so on.

Right now our POC is crash test, we go on a field, get another robot and crash with max accel from both robots.

Yet I think we miss stuff, like yeah, ofcourse I can not predict that an encoder will randomly start doing problems, but it just happens too many times to be called “randomly”.

So yeah, I am curious what do you guys do to make sure your robot can work on the field each match without stopping mid match.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-03-24T21:41:42.141Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":429,"readers_count":428,"score":110.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459931,"topic_slug":"how-to-build-a-product","display_username":"Amit sucher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55442,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Amit 6738"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-build-a-product/459931/1","custom_user_title":"Amit 6738","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3342407,"name":"Jeremiah Johnson","username":"Johnsonjer","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/9d8465/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T04:41:36.289Z","cooked":"

The #1 reason I’ve found for failures mid-match are wiring-related.

Specifically, at Northern Lights Regional our robot quit mid-match three times during qualifications. Several other times we lost function of subsystems. Several times our can wires jostled loose and we lost the use of our intake. One time we lost power and another time we lost radio communication - both of which were temporary but we didn’t notice reconnection until the end of the match. The last time we actually pressed our own power button with our intake and shut ourselves down completely.

CAN wire has been a major problem for us this year and we’ve been slowly working towards solutions. At the Iowa Regional over the weekend we did not have a single CAN wire issue. However, we did have a Rev Neo 550 encoder wire connector become troublesome at the SparkMax so our solution was to hot glue it in place.

We’re also very annoyed with the PWM connectors with clips for CAN wire so we’ve purchased various 22awg 2-pin connectors to try during the off-season. Most of which were recommended in various CD threads.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T04:41:36.289Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":270,"readers_count":269,"score":69.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":459931,"topic_slug":"how-to-build-a-product","display_username":"Jeremiah Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61884,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6419M, 648A"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-build-a-product/459931/2","custom_user_title":"6419M, 648A","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342476,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T06:07:24.472Z","cooked":"

Run practice matches with a second robot (can be just a drivetrain). Drive it as hard as possible and break it as much as possible early on doing match simulation - don’t get too attached to anything on the robot because it’s probably going to break a few times. Nothing teaches good wire management like watching your robot fail a few times because of it. Use connectors and components that are recommended by other teams. If something fails during your practice match at home… play through the match. See what happens if your robot is forced to play without a critical function (well, except maybe for drivetrain). You have to start doing this around Week 4 or 5 to make sure you have time to iterate all the stuff that breaks before your events.

Tie all your wires down, strain relieve everything, don’t have exposed wires or motors around your chassis, and bring a spare for every mechanism. 2 or 3 spare intakes as well. Dabs of hot glue on critical connectors, being careful not to get any inside the ports! Tape over your RoboRIO I/O ports. Put that piece of tape over the metal plate in the radio. Use nylocks or Grasshopper nuts on your batteries. Use nylocks on your main breaker studs.

Tug test all your critical wires before each match. I recommend having a laminated checklist you can check off one item at a time before each match. That’s all your ethernet cables, radio power path, RoboRIO power path, PDH input power wires, breaker lugs, and battery lugs. Probably best to do the drivetrain as well, but that might be getting into redundancy territory.

Above all, enforce a culture of excellence. Don’t let members do sketchy stuff on the robot. Prioritize always having a functional robot, and make sure nothing that goes into the robot is a “well, I guess this works”. Remake parts if you need to. Tug tests everyone’s crimps and make sure that they know that sloppy work is unacceptable.

It’s not a sin to write off a product line if you have bad experiences. Some people like to blame teams for problems with a product, but if your team has an issue with a product, feel free not to use it until you feel like there’s a compelling reason to go back. Ethernet switch doesn’t work? Blacklist the brand.
